image.altText: Two police officers in uniform stand and look at the bottom of an overturned bus

items.synopsis: Police allege the driver "lost control" of a wedding bus as it entered a roundabout before crashing in NSW's Hunter Valley on Sunday night, killing 10 people.

title.children: Bus driver going 'too quick' before fatal crash in NSW's Hunter Valley, police allege

image.altText: Man in hat, woman in dress hold hands

items.synopsis: Twenty-four hours after a horror bus crash killed 10 wedding guests, there have been prayers, candles and a guernsey tribute.

title.children: Two victims identified, as communities grieve brutal Hunter Valley crash

image.altText: Fiona Mardling smiling in a portrait, wearing a blue clinic uniform and a stethscope around her neck.

items.synopsis: Nurses outside of hospitals say they are not being used to their full capacity, with one group blaming Medicare rules for holding them back.

title.children: 'I feel very frustrated': Fiona is a highly trained nurse who spends her days changing dressings

image.altText: One hand on a laptop's trackpad while another hand holds a credit card

items.synopsis: Fraudulent sites are mimicking real brands, going as far as stealing logos and brand design. Melinda did the checks but they weren't enough — so here are the signs to look out for.

title.children: Fake websites are getting slicker and mimicking real brands. Melinda fell for one and wants others to know the signs

image.altText: Black a frame with sign saying fever clinic and a yellow arrow, sitting in front of a red wall with 'emergency' written on it

items.synopsis: Each Omicron wave has had distinguishing features and Australia's fifth wave has grown so slowly many may not have realised it had begun. So why has this most recent wave been so drawn out, and what has its impact been on our health and health systems?

title.children: Australia is in another COVID wave, but it's not like the others

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

items.synopsis: With only 24 hours in a day, researchers have crunched the numbers and worked out what the average global human day looks like.

title.children: This is what the average human day looks like. How do Australians compare?

image.altText: A man with a small moustache and dressed in camo sits inside a military vehicle

items.synopsis: As Ukrainian forces continue their push in and around Bakhmut, soldiers returned from the frontline say the Australian-built armoured personnel carrier is helping keep them alive.

title.children: 'If the Australians were around, I would hug them': Ukraine's soldiers thrilled with Bushmaster performance on battlefield

image.altText: More revelations in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation

items.synopsis: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay about $430 million to settle a lawsuit by Jeffrey Epstein's victims who had accused the bank of being the financial conduit that allowed him to continue operating a sex trafficking operation.

title.children: Jeffrey Epstein victims reach $430 million settlement with JPMorgan Chase bank

image.altText: A composite image including the Karen's Diner sign and a notice on the door showing a termination of the lease.

items.synopsis: Viral social media restaurants Karen's Diner close, leaving former workers alleging sexual and physical harassment claims in doubt.

title.children: Karen's Diner employees' concerns remain unresolved as liquidators appointed to multiple restaurants

image.altText: Three flight attendants — a man in a dark suit, and two women wearing red and black dresses — stand in a plane smiling.

items.synopsis: The airline is scrapping its gender-based uniform guidelines — and it's not the first, with many airlines having updated their rules to allow staff to show their authentic selves.

title.children: Qantas to allow flat shoes, make-up and long hair on crew of any gender — but what does this mean for inclusivity?

image.altText: First-term Labor MP Michelle Ananda-Rajah sits in parliament.

items.synopsis: Labor backbencher Michelle Ananda-Rajah said on Q+A that there are 122,000 people sleeping rough. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked first-term Labor MP Michelle Ananda-Rajah on rough sleepers. Here's what we found

image.altText: A Parramatta NRL player with a cut in the corner of his left eye flicks a pass to his left during a game.

items.synopsis: NSW make four changes for Origin II on June 21, with Parramatta playmaker Mitchell Moses and Souths hooker Damien Cook coming in along with two debutants.

title.children: NSW bring in four players to side for Origin II

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios stands on a grass court, wearing his cap backwards, and points a finger after winning a tennis match.

items.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios is to make his long-awaited return after seven months sidelined, taking to the grass in Stuttgart in preparation for his return to Wimbledon.

title.children: Nick Kyrgios 'super-excited' to make court comeback on grass in Stuttgart

image.altText: Yasir Al Rumayyan speaks to Dustin Johnson while holding the trophy at a LIV Golf event

items.synopsis: What the PGA Tour-PIF deal shows is that as heinous as some of Saudi Arabia's crimes are, the stakes involved in strategic global alignments are much higher, and the USA is willing to look beyond human rights abuses when necessary, writes Tracey Holmes.

title.children: Terrorism, big business and foreign policy — the reshaping of global golf

image.altText: Aerial photo of a block of new-looking houses and a road with farmland around the development.

items.synopsis: The state government faces pressure to abandon a pilot program that allows developers to bypass councils to nominate major housing projects.

title.children: NSW councils condemn 'secret' housing rezoning process for major developments

image.altText: A man smiling standing in front of a cool room fridge of lamb

items.synopsis: Farmer Colin Harper was fed up with being a price taker — and not a price maker — when it came to selling his lambs. To solve the problem, the Riverina farmer decided to step away from the saleyards.

title.children: Sick of having lamb prices dictated to him by supermarkets, this farmer went direct to the customer

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: Former US attorney-general William Barr says Donald Trump is "toast" if allegations that he wilfully retained hundreds of highly classified documents are proven true under Special Counsel Jack Smith's 37-count indictment against the former president.

title.children: Donald Trump's former attorney-general says 'he's toast' if indictment allegations are true

image.altText: A sign outside Banksia Hill Detention Centre with a police officer nearby.

items.synopsis: The WA Department of Justice is accused of intimidating and bullying staff who speak about Western Australia's juvenile detention facilities, including by warning them about possible jail time.

title.children: 'Cease immediately': Leaked email shows warning to Banksia Hill officers over workplace conversations

image.altText: An older woman in a light green t-shirt sits on a couch next to a younger woman in a green top.

items.synopsis: Born without a uterus, Prue always wanted children of her own. After trialling different options for a baby, a family friend offered her a transplant.

title.children: A family friend's gift gives Prue the chance to have a baby

image.altText: A woman in a white shirt smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Patients will no longer have to travel hundreds of kilometres or pay thousands in up front costs as a bulk-billed care centre opens in the NSW Riverina.

title.children: Cancer patient's travel time cut from four hours to two minutes

image.altText: Silvio Berlusconi looks into the distance.

items.synopsis: The controversial politician and media mogul has died in hospital in Milan after suffering from leukaemia for "some time".

title.children: Former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi dies, aged 86

image.altText: An ASX board shot by John Gunn in Deccember 2022.

items.synopsis: The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq jump to a 13-month high, boosted by tech stocks. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street rallies as investors hope US central bank will pause rate hikes, ASX set to rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has indicated it will implement 14 out of 22 recommendations from Michelle Levy's review of financial advice, but will not remove the best interest duty on advice provided by banks, insurers and fund managers. "We can't ignore the findings of the Hayne royal commission and we can't ignore the events that have led to the situation where we are today," said Financial Services Minister Stephen Jones on RN Breakfast this morning. "I'd characterise the government's response as cautious." However, the changes will remove potential legal barriers for super funds to provide more generalised financial advice and will also see some of the more onerous paperwork requirements removed from financial planners. Ms Levy's review was commissioned by the previous Coalition government after thousands of advisers left the industry, pushing up the cost of advice. You can listen to Mr Jones's full interview with Hamish Macdonald on the RN Breakfast website.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Banks will not be exempted from best interests duty on financial advice

featuredLink.title: Government to unveil changes to financial advice rules - ABC Radio National

children.content: The federal government has indicated it will implement 14 out of 22 recommendations from Michelle Levy's review of financial advice, but will not remove the best interest duty on advice provided by banks, insurers and fund managers.

"We can't ignore the findings of the Hayne royal commission and we can't ignore the events that have led to the situation where we are today," said Financial Services Minister Stephen Jones on RN Breakfast this morning.
"I'd characterise the government's response as cautious."

However, the changes will remove potential legal barriers for super funds to provide more generalised financial advice and will also see some of the more onerous paperwork requirements removed from financial planners.
Ms Levy's review was commissioned by the previous Coalition government after thousands of advisers left the industry, pushing up the cost of advice.
You can listen to Mr Jones's full interview with Hamish Macdonald on the RN Breakfast website.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some good news for motorists, at the expense of Russia and Saudi Arabia. The price of oil dropped steeply overnight, with Brent crude down 4% to $US71.97. The story is, of course, one of supply and demand. In this case, demand from China's economic reopening is weaker than expected, but the supply story is far more intriguing. "The market is becoming increasingly concerned over the potential of a supply war between Saudi Arabia and Russia," wrote NAB's Rodrigo Catril this morning. " Saudi Arabia is trying to reduce supply and last week the largest global oil exporter, announced a plan to decrease output by 1 million barrels per day (bpd) in July, bringing it down to 9m bpd. "But with Russia in need of money to fund its Ukraine invasion, we now know that Russian oil exports to China and India surged to record high levels in May. "The contrasting Saudi vs Russia supply strategies are now causing tensions in the market, further exacerbated by a sluggish recovery of Chinese demand. "Not helping sentiment, overnight, Goldman Sachs revised down its oil price forecasts for the third time in six months."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are Saudi Arabia and Russia falling into an oil war?

children.content: Some good news for motorists, at the expense of Russia and Saudi Arabia.
The price of oil dropped steeply overnight, with
Brent crude down 4% to $US71.97
The story is, of course, one of supply and demand. In this case, demand from China's economic reopening is weaker than expected, but the supply story is far more intriguing.
"The market is becoming increasingly concerned over the potential of a supply war between Saudi Arabia and Russia," wrote NAB's Rodrigo Catril this morning.
Saudi Arabia is trying to reduce supply
and last week the largest global oil exporter, announced a plan to decrease output by 1 million barrels per day (bpd) in July, bringing it down to 9m bpd.
"But with Russia in need of money to fund its Ukraine invasion, we now know that
Russian oil exports to China and India surged to record high levels in May

Goldman Sachs revised down its oil price forecasts
for the third time in six months."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets blog. It's been a good night on Wall Street as investors hope the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold this week at 5 to 5.25 per cent. The S & P 500 and the Nasdaq closed at the highest since April last year, with the benchmark index in a bull market. The S & P 500 is up by 21 per cent from its low in October last year. Tech heavyweights drove the market and software firm Oracle hit a record high ahead of its quarterly results. Consumer prices are predicted to have cooled in May and traders see a 76 per cent chance the Fed will pause its rate hikes this week. Grab some coffee and let's go.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks hit highest since April

children.content: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets blog.
It's been a good night on Wall Street as investors hope the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold this week at 5 to 5.25 per cent.
The S
P 500 and the Nasdaq closed at the highest since April last year, with the benchmark index in a bull market.
The S
P 500 is up by 21 per cent from its low in October last year.
Tech heavyweights drove the market and software firm Oracle hit a record high ahead of its quarterly results.
Consumer prices are predicted to have cooled in May and traders see a 76 per cent chance the Fed will pause its rate hikes this week.
Grab some coffee and let's go.

image.altText: A man speaks into a megaphone surrounded by journalists outside in PNG

items.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's former prime minister, Peter O'Neill, is charged with giving false evidence after a commission of inquiry recommends he be prosecuted.

image.altText: Ben Stokes walks with the sun framing his head

title.children: Australia set for first look at England's Bazball revolution

title.children: Rescued child says mother survived for days in jungle after plane crash

image.altText: Ukrainian serviceman sits atop a tank, amid Russia's attack on Ukraine, in Donetsk region.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says troops recaptured seven villages from Russian forces in the south-east, as France promises more military aid to Kyiv to help with its counteroffensive.

title.children: Ukrainian troops retake villages while Russia says it repelled new offences

image.altText: Composite image of Shellie Morris, Astrid Jorgenson, Tim Winton and Barry Humphries.

items.synopsis: Prominent Australians including author Tim Winton and late comedian Barry Humphries are appointed to the Order of Australia, in the first year women outnumber men on the honours list.

title.children: 'Life's great, I love it': The passionate Australians being honoured this King's Birthday

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff with Michael Ferguson at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Transparency and integrity experts criticise the Tasmanian government's reliance on claims of cabinet confidentiality to avoid releasing departmental advice about its controversial plan to build a stadium on Hobart's waterfront.

title.children: Transparency experts slam Tasmanian government secrecy over planned stadium

image.altText: Woman stands next to a white ute, brown boder collie dogs sits in the tray.

items.synopsis: After five fatal dog attacks in the past year, these Wheatbelt farmers are pleading with pet owners to do more to protect livestock in the region.

title.children: 'Animals are found alive that shouldn't be' after dog attacks

image.altText: A marijuna plant.

items.synopsis: Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research findings suggest the NSW Cannabis Caution Scheme has "indirect bias" built into its eligibility criteria.

title.children: Claims of police bias as study finds Aboriginal adults caught with cannabis more likely to be charged

image.altText: Black-and-white image of a man sunbaking on a beach.

items.synopsis: He was one of the most prolific Australian photographers of the 20th century, but these lesser-known Max Dupain works have escaped the public eye for decades.

title.children: He's best known for the Sunbaker, but one chapter of photographer Max Dupain's life remains largely forgotten
